questions.text:
A 21-year-old medical student presented to the dermatology OPD with the following image on the sole and a diagnosis of warts is being made. All of the following statements are true except?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: HPV 2 is the most common causative organism in Superficial plantar warts
Deep palmoplantar warts are also called Myrmecia warts
HPV 6 is the most common causative organism in Anogenital warts

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cryotherapy is a painless procedure

 

Explanation:

The main disadvantage of Cryotherapy / Freezing is pain.

 

Cryotherapy:

  • Liquid nitrogen, carbon dioxide snow, and dimethyl ether can all cause thermal injury to the skin. Liquid nitrogen, which is frequently employed in practice, produces the coldest freeze.
  • A cotton wool bud or cryospray is applied until a rim of iced tissue forms around the wart (visible as a white discoloration).
  • Depending on the size and location of the wart, the freezing is maintained for 5 to 30 seconds, therefore scarring is unlikely.
  • Cryotherapy is safer than imiquimod, podophyllin, and podofilox, which are teratogenic.


Plantar warts:

  • Verruca vulgaris (common wart) is most commonly caused by HPV types 1, 4, 27, and 57. 
    Plantar warts are mainly caused by HPV 1 (deep plantar) and HPV 2 (superficial plantar warts) (Option A).
  • Common warts typically have no symptoms and appear as firm papules with a rough, horny surface. Histologically, they exhibit acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and papillomatosis.
  • Deep palmoplantar warts are also called myrmecia warts (Option B).
  • Verruca plana (flat warts) are flat-surfaced lesions, mainly caused by HPV types 3 and 10.
  • Anogenital warts are most commonly caused by HPV 6 and HPV 11 (Option C).

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with painful and pruritic lesions 2 days after developing a fever. She had a similar history of lesions in the past associated with fever which resolved spontaneously. What is the likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cold sore

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of a patient with painful and pruritic lesions (small, closely grouped vesicles) associated with fever in the past presenting with similar symptoms suggests herpes labialis (cold sore).

Herpes labialis/cold sore:

  • Reactivation of latent infection in trigeminal ganglion, causing asymptomatic shedding or clinically evident recurrent disease.
  • Causative organism: HSV-1 > HSV-2.

Features:

  • Painful and pruritic lesions.
  • Fever is often present, which subsides in 3-5 days. The initial vesicular lesions become pustular and then crusted before healing in 7-10 days without scarring.
  • Can be associated with itching or burning before the development of lesions.
  • Recurrent herpetic lesions are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.

Treatment:

Treatment Line

Drugs

First Line
  • Acyclovir (topical/oral)
  • Hydrocolloid dressing

Other Drugs
  • Topical penciclovir
  • Prophylactic acyclovir

 

Varicella (Option A) presents with papules and vesicles on an erythematous base with a centripetal distribution associated with systemic symptoms of fever and malaise.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option C) presents with shiny, pearly white umbilicated papules.

Whitlow (Option D) presents with painful swelling of the fingertips and periungual area due to herpes infection by inoculation.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male visited the outpatient department with persistent vesicular eruptions on his lips as shown in the image. Despite multiple previous treatments with oral antiviral medication, the lesions have not shown signs of improvement. Considering acyclovir-resistant recurrent herpes labialis, which of the following alternative drugs could be considered for treatment?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Foscarnet.

 

Explanation:

  • Acyclovir is the cornerstone therapy for herpes infections because it is a competitive inhibitor of viral DNA polymerase.
  • It requires phosphorylation, to be converted to its active form.
  • Resistance occurs primarily due to
    • Mutations in the viral thymidine kinase (TK) gene
    • Alterations in viral DNA polymerase that diminish the ability of acyclovir to be phosphorylated into its active form
  • Clinically, acyclovir-resistant herpes infections may manifest as persistent or recurrent lesions that do not respond to standard acyclovir therapy
  • Alternative antiviral agents such as foscarnet, cidofovir, or brivudine may be considered for treatment.

Lamivudine (Option A) – Not effective against herpes viruses; primarily used for hepatitis B and HIV as a reverse transcriptase inhibitor.


Valacyclovir (Option C) – A prodrug of acyclovir, requiring thymidine kinase activation, and thus ineffective in acyclovir-resistant herpes.


Ganciclovir (Option D) – Primarily used for cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections; requires phosphorylation for activation, making it less effective against acyclovir-resistant herpes.

questions.text: A primigravida at 38 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department in labor with symptoms of fever, headache, and genital itching. Upon examination, the cervix is found to be dilated at 7 cm, and small painful blisters with ulceration are observed around the vulva, along with inguinal lymphadenopathy. Select the incorrect statement regarding this presentation.

choices.text: Cesarean section may reduce the risk of infection in the baby
In the case of neonatal transmission, mortality rates are typically low
This condition is commonly caused by HSV-2
Prophylactic acyclovir should be considered for her neonate.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) In the case of neonatal transmission, mortality rates are typically low.

 

Explanation:

  • The above scenario is suggestive of active primary genital herpes in the mother most commonly caused by HSV 2.
  • Neonatal herpes is transmitted from mother to newborn during childbirth or within 28 days of it
  • Neonatal herpes has a high mortality of >60%.

 

Features of Neonatal Herpes

Localized Disease:

  • Symptoms localized to the skin, eyes, or mouth.
  • Infants may present with vesicular lesions, ulcerations, or erythema in these areas.

 

Disseminated Disease:

  • Includes hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, jaundice, respiratory distress, and coagulopathy. Disseminated disease can rapidly progress to multiorgan failure.
  • Associated with high mortality in neonates ~85%

 

Herpes Simplex Encephalitis:

  • Infants may present with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, irritability, lethargy, and poor feeding, which can rapidly progress to seizures, altered consciousness, focal neurologic deficits, and coma.
  • Most common part involved here is temporal lobe

Neonatal herpes is treated with high-dose intravenous acyclovir followed by oral acyclovir for 6 months.

 

Treatment of Herpes during pregnancy:

Current Active Lesion

Acyclovir 5 x 200mg for 10 days
History of Active lesions in pregnancy Acyclovir from 36 weeks gestational age till delivery
If active lesions present during labor LSCS

 

Cesarean section may reduce the risk of infection in the baby (Option A) – C-section is recommended to prevent neonatal herpes transmission in mothers with active genital lesions during labor.


This condition is commonly caused by HSV-2 (Option C) – Genital herpes is most often caused by HSV-2, though HSV-1 can also be responsible in some cases.


Prophylactic acyclovir should be considered for her neonate (Option D) – Neonates exposed to HSV should receive IV acyclovir promptly to reduce the risk of severe complications.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old child develops round, firm, and painless bumps over the face. All of the following statements about this disease are true except?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Spread direct skin-to-skin contact with an infected person
RNA virus is the causative agent
Lesions are not seen in palms & Soles generally

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) RNA virus is a causative agent

 

Explanation:

The above image shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with central umbilication which are suggestive of Molluscum contagiosum, caused by a double stranded DNA virus

Virus:

  • Molluscum contagiosum, Virus (MCV).
  • Types of MCV:
    • MCV-1 Children Face (Not seen over palms & soles) (Option D ruled out)
    • MCV-2 Adults-it produces lesions over the genital area.
  • Transmission: Spread direct skin-to-skin contact with an infected person. (Option A ruled out)
  • Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon: New lesions develop along the line of trauma due to Autoinoculation. (Option C ruled out)
  • Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area (in adults)
  • Microscopic examination of the lesions shows eosinophilic inclusions called Henderson-Patterson bodies. (See image below)
  • Giant (>1cm) or widespread Molluscum contagiosum are seen in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Treatment
    • Usually, it is self-limiting. Thus, There is no need for treatment.
    • Destruction with cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, diluted liquefied phenol, or surgical removal are a few options considered for severe cases.

Correct Answer: A) Coxsackievirus A16

 

Explanation:

The image shows vesicles on palms, soles, and oral mucosa suggestive of hand-foot-and-mouth disease.

 

Hand-foot-mouth disease:

Exanthematous fever, which mainly affects young children, is characterized by clusters of papulovesicular lesions on the skin and oral mucosa.

 

 

Etiology:

  • Coxsackievirus A16 (M/C cause)
  • Coxsackievirus A6 (causes more severe disease)
  • Coxsackievirus B 1-3
  • Enterovirus 71

Transmission: Droplets or fecal transmission.

Features:

  • Oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash on palms and soles may spread to the arms, legs, oral cavity, and buttocks.
  • Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from vesicles of herpes and pox viruses.
  • Usually a benign illness, resolving in 1-2 weeks.

Complications:

  • Aseptic meningitis
  • Encephalitis
  • Flaccid paralysis
  • Pulmonary haemorrhage

 

Pox virus (Option B) causes diseases such as smallpox (a deep-seated rash with slow evolution and centrifugal distribution) and molluscum contagiosum (which spares palms and soles).


Herpes virus (Option C): While certain herpes viruses can cause oral lesions (like HSV-1) and others can cause systemic symptoms (like varicella-zoster virus), they do not typically cause the hand-foot-mouth disease pattern.


Human papillomavirus (Option D) causes warts and is not typically associated with the systemic presentation of hand, foot, and mouth disease with oral sores.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding Herpes zoster (Shingles).

choices.text: Varicella-zoster virus remains dormant in Dorsal root ganglion
Thoracic and lumbar dermatomes are most commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Maculopapular rash is seen.

 

Explanation:

Herpes zoster:

  • A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).
  • Herpes zoster (shingles) leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution (shown in the image mentioned below).

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

  • Is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection,
    • Infectious period: 2 days before the development of rash till all the lesions have crusted.
    • Pleomorphic rash, distributed mainly over the trunk.
    • Vesicles: Dew drops on rose petal appearance.
  • It then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia (Option A) for variable periods.
  • It can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles), which leads to vesicular lesions grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved (Option D)

Symptoms:

  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages ( Thoracic and lumbar dermatomes). The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.

Treatment:

  • Zoster is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia.
  • All cases of herpes zoster should be treated with Acyclovir, administered at a dosage of 800 mg five times a day. It is most effective when the treatment is initiated within 72 hours of the onset of infection.

questions.text:
An immunocompromised individual presents with a corrugated white lesion on the side of the tongue as shown in the image below, which does not wipe off. The most likely causative agent is?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Epstein Barr Virus (EBV)

 

Explanation:

  • It is known to cause oral hairy Leukoplakia, an EBV-induced lesion typically occurring in immunocompromised individuals.
  • The lesion appears as a white, corrugated (or hairy) patch that cannot be wiped off, which matches the presentation in the image.

Disease associated with EBV

Pathognomonic Findings

Classic Symptoms

Infectious Mononucleosis

Atypical lymphocytosis, positive heterophile antibody test, elevated liver enzymes
  • Fever
  • Pharyngitis, Lymphadenopathy (posterior cervical)
  • Splenomegaly

Burkitt Lymphoma

"Starry sky" appearance on histology
  • Rapidly growing jaw or abdominal mass

Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

Undifferentiated carcinoma with EBV DNA in tumor cells
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis
  • Hearing loss
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy

Hodgkin Lymphoma

Reed-Sternberg cells on histology
  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss), pruritus

Oral Hairy Leukoplakia

White, hairy patches on lateral tongue, non-scrapable
  • Asymptomatic, common in immunocompromised individuals

EBV-associated Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)

Hemophagocytosis in bone marrow/tissues
  • Fever
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Cytopenias
  • Hyperferritinemia
  • Hypertriglyceridemia

Gastric Carcinoma

EBV DNA in gastric carcinoma
  • Weight loss
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea and Vomiting

Incorrect Options:

Candida (Option A): It typically causes oral thrush, which presents as white plaques that can be wiped off, unlike the corrugated lesion shown in the image.

 

Candida lesions that cannot be wiped off:

  • Chronic Hyperplastic Candidiasis
  • Erythematous Candidiasis

Human Herpes Virus (HHV6) (Option C): It is not commonly associated with oral lesions in immunocompromised patients. HHV-6 more often reactivates to cause roseola in infants or is asymptomatic in adults.


Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) (Option D): It is associated with Kaposi's sarcoma, not corrugated white oral lesions. Kaposi's sarcoma typically presents as red or purple lesions in the oral cavity or on the skin.

questions.text:
Three days ago, a mother brought her 1-year-old infant to the emergency room with a high fever. The infant was treated with acetaminophen. Today, the fever is gone, but the infant has developed a rash on the trunk that has spread to the limbs. The examination reveals red papules on the palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?





{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Roseola infantum

 

Explanation:

  • Roseola infantum, caused by Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6), is a common exanthematous fever in children under 2 years old.
  • The characteristic lack of symptoms during the febrile phase followed by the appearance of a rosy rash on the trunk and neck after 3 days of high fever is suggestive of Roseola.
  • Nagayama spots, red papules over the palate, are pathognomonic, and cervical and occipital lymph nodes are typically enlarged.

Commonly confused rash-associated illnesses in children are:
 

 

Rubella

Roseola

Measles

Fever

Prodrome of high fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis.

Abrupt onset of high fever (>39°C) without any other symptoms.

Prodrome of high fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis.

PathognomonicFeatures

Presence of posterior auricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy

Nagayama spots, red papules over the palate

Koplik spots, small white lesions on the buccal mucosa, appear 1 to 2 days before the rash

Rash

Starts on the face and spreads downward to the trunk and extremities.

 

The rash consists of discrete pink-red macules that may coalesce.

The rash may spread to the extremities, face, and occasionally palms and soles

The rash starts as erythematous macules on the face, then spreads cephalocaudally, becoming confluent.

Day of onset of Rash

14-17

3-5 (after fever subsides)

3-7
 

 


 

Erythema infectiosum (Option B):

  • Aka Fifth Disease; caused by parvovirus B19, while roseola is caused by HHV-6.
  • It presents with a "slapped cheek" rash followed by a lace-like rash on the trunk, unlike roseola, which starts on the trunk after the fever subsides.
  • Glove and stocking neuropathy
  • Rheumatoid arthritis like illness in adults

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida is living with her nephew, who has recently developed varicella. She has no history of varicella exposure or vaccination, and serological testing reveals that she is not immune to the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Based on this information, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) She is susceptible to chickenpox

 

Explanation:

  • The absence of antibodies against VZV indicates that the patient is susceptible to primary VZV infection, commonly known as chickenpox.
  • VZV causes exanthematous lesions in children (chickenpox), in adults (shingles or zoster), and in pregnancy.

 

Varicella zoster (Chickenpox) in pregnancy:

  • Chickenpox in pregnancy can affect both the mother and the fetus. Mothers are at high risk of developing varicella pneumonia. The fetus can develop two types of infection, depending on the gestational period at which it acquires the infection.
  • When maternal varicella occurs during the first half of pregnancy, the fetal infection can be asymptomatic or can manifest as congenital varicella syndrome, characterized by:

Most characteristic anomalies

Cicatrizing skin lesions and limb hypoplasia

CNS defects

Microcephaly, mental retardation, and seizures

Ocular defects

Chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, and cataract

Renal system defects

Hydroureter and hydronephrosis

ANS defect

Neurogenic bladder

Others

Low birth weight

When the fetal infection occurs near delivery, the baby may develop congenital (neonatal varicella) within two weeks of birth:

If the mother develops chickenpox >5 days before delivery

The baby is mostly asymptomatic due to protective maternal antibody which prevents the transmission of the virus during delivery

If the mother develops chickenpox 5 days before to 2 days after delivery

Maternal antibodies would not have been produced in such a short time → The virus is dispersed in the baby → Neonatal varicella, a severe form with a high mortality rate (high risk of pneumonia and encephalitis).

 

Susceptibility to Herpes Zoster (Shingles) in Pregnancy:

  • Though herpes zoster has a very low infectivity rate, since there are no antibodies in the mother, she is susceptible to the infection.


Management:

  • Any patient diagnosed with primary varicella infection or herpes zoster should be isolated from pregnant women.
  • Exposed gravidas with a negative clinical history or prior chickenpox or vaccination should undergo VZV serological testing. At least 70% of these women will be seropositive and thus immune.
  • Indications for VZIG administration: Best given within 96 hours of exposure 
  • Immunocompromised patients without evidence of immunity.
  • Newborn infants whose mothers have signs and symptoms of varicella around the time of delivery (i.e., 5 days before to 2 days after).
  • Hospitalized premature infants born at ≥28 weeks of gestation whose mothers do not have evidence of immunity to varicella.
  • Hospitalized premature infants born at <28 weeks of gestation or who weigh ≤1,000 g at birth, regardless of their mother’s evidence of immunity to varicella.
  • Pregnant women without evidence of immunity.

 

She is susceptible to zoster (Option A): Zoster, or shingles, occurs in individuals who have had chickenpox in the past and the virus reactivates. Since the patient has never had chickenpox, she is not at risk for zoster until she has had a primary VZV infection.


She is immune to zoster (Option C): Immunity to zoster implies that the patient has had a prior infection with VZV, which is not the case here as evidenced by the negative antibody test.


She is immune to chickenpox (Option D): A negative varicella antibody test indicates that the patient does not have immunity to chickenpox.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Human papillomavirus 6 and 11

 

Explanation:

The above shows rough finger-like, cauliflower-like growth over the vulva is suggestive of condyloma accuminata, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV 6 > HPV 11).

 

Condyloma acuminata (anogenital warts):

  • Benign, moist, soft, pedunculated wart found on the external genitalia and has low malignant potential.
  • Site: They may be found in the genital area such as the penile shaft, scrotum, or labia majora of the vagina, or in the anal area.
  • Microscopy:
    • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma.
    • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening).
    • Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is Characteristic.
    • No evidence of dysplasia.

The table below shows the clinical features of HPV and the types responsible for various lesions:

Clinical lesion

Oncogenic potential

HPV types

Plantar warts

Benign

1

Common skin warts

Benign

2, 4, 27, 57

Epidermodysplasia verrucosa

Mostly benign, rarely progresses to malignancy

5, 8, 9, 12, 17

Anogenital warts

Laryngeal papilloma

Intraepithelial neoplasia

Low malignant potential

6, 11

Palmar warts in butchers

Low malignant potential

7

Carcinomas of the cervix & other genital mucosa/larynx/oesophagus

High malignant potential

16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68

 

Treponema pallidum (Option A) causes syphilis, leading to condyloma lata during the secondary stage. These broad, moist lesions appear in areas like the genital and perianal regions, differing from HPV-induced condyloma acuminata.

 

Human papillomavirus 16 and 18 (Option C) are associated with carcinoma of the cervix and anogenital region.

Haemophilus ducreyi (Option D) causes chancroid. It presents as a painful, non-indurated ulcer with undermined edges and tender inguinal buboes. Microscopy shows a school of fish/railroad track appearance.
